value: caption=The beach at Ryde on the Isle of Wight. The tower visible is the Spinnaker in Portsmouth.

is the largest town on the

Ryde is situated in the north-east of the island, with its grand Georgian and Victorian houses, it rises up from the 1/2 mile long pier and into the hills behind. The pier was built in 1814 and now houses the high speed ferry link operated by Wightlink to and from

, as well as the terminus for the island's electric railway which runs to Shanklin. The pier is one of only a few in the country that you can drive your car along and park it at the end for the ferry.

The long High street houses a wide variety of shops and boutiques and takes you down to the Esplanade with its golden sand beaches and wide choice of activities. The Esplanade consists of a ten-pin bowling alley, indoor ice rink, swimming pool, and a nightclub as well as numerous amusement arcades and children's play areas.

Further from the Esplanade, is the Promenade which stretches from the esplanade to Puckpool Park. Along the Promenade is Appley Tower, a Victorian Folly and nearby is Appley gardens.

value: runs just about every half hour in the summer.

Island Line trains run a regular service from the Fastcat terminal at the pier head.  this stops at: Ryde Esplanade, Ryde St John's, Smallbrook Junction,
has a bus terminal at the foot of the pier adjacent to the Ryde Esplanade railway station.
